repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Nairobi Water and Sewerage
            Institutional Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Nairobi Water and
            Sewerage Institutional Restructuring Project for Kenya were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: there should be
            a champion capable of leading sector reform activities. The
            Ministry of Water and Irrigation (MOWI) took leadership for
            the sector reform and continuously followed up on the
            implementation of this reform. It was also important that
            Athi Water Services Board (AWSB) and Nairobi City Water and
            Sewerage Company (NWSC) were championing and piloting the
            day-to-day implementation of the sector reform, and that
            both agencies were well suited to do so because of the
            capacity they already had and which they were constantly
            increasing throughout the project's implementation
            period. The project focused its support on one water service
            board and one water service provider only. By doing so the
            project avoided overstretching financial resources as well
            as implementation capacity on the Borrower's and the
            Bank's side. With the selection of AWSB and NWSC as the
            agencies for implementing the sector reform first, the
            project focused on stakeholders which already had some
            capacity which increased the likelihood of success.
